title: The Age of American Impressionism: Masterpieces from the Art Institute of Chicago
copy: The Art Institute of Chicago, although renowned for its holdings of works by the French Impressionists, also houses a wealth of superb examples by American proponents of this distinctive style. The breadth of the museum's collection of American Impressionism is rich, with a substantial body of paintings and watercolors by Winslow Homer, who is seen today as a precursor to Impressionism, as well as impressive portfolios of work by Americans living in Europe, such as James McNeill Whistler and John Singer Sargent, and the only American who was officially part of the French group, Mary Cassatt. In addition, important paintings and watercolors by notable artists such as Cecilia Beaux, William Merritt Chase, Childe Hassam, George Inness, Mauric Prendergast, and John Twachtman are included, along with handsomely reproduced images by lesser-known artists who worked in the Impressionist vein.   Edited by Judith A. Barter With contributions by Judith A. Barter, Sarah Kelly Oehler, Denise Mahoney, and Ellen E. Roberts   160 pages, 9 1/2 x 12 in. 117 color ills. Out of print ISBN: 978-0-86559-250-6 (softcover) ISBN: 978-300-17574-5 (hardcover)
